subject: RE: [junit] Re: Any plans to revamp junit?
msgSnippet: Because we of course desire a framework with known and long-standing bugs in it, whose purpose to help others confront and fix their bugs. Because when
messageBody:
Because we of course desire a framework with known and long-standing bugs in it, whose purpose to help others confront and fix their bugs.

Because when something is flawed, but good enough - we should never strive to make it better for fear that it will spiral out of control because of the dread disease "featuritis". Instead we should learn to accept something, in all of its flaws, as "just good enough".

This email brought to you by the letter 'K' and the number '3'.


Chip
-----
"The reason the mainstream is thought of as a stream is because it's so shallow" --George Carlin

Subject: Re: [junit] Re: Any plans to revamp junit?


Timothy Wall wrote:

> On Jul 13, 2004, at 7:07 AM, Ilja Preuss wrote:
>
> > Bill de hSra wrote:
> >> J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> >
> >>> How many such fixes are there, though, really? There's the
> >>> classloader fix, and the string compares fix, and other than that,
> >>> everything else is merely an extension, isn't it? (I'm talking about
> >>> DbUnit, HtmlUnit, HttpUnit, XMLUnit, ...)
> >>
> >> How many is a red herring.
> >
> > Is it? If there aren't many fixes that needed to be integrated, how
> > much
> > of a problem is it?
>
> Depends on the seriousness of the problem. Sure, you can rely on
> everyone to implement workarounds or their own fixes (e.g.
> testrunners), but what's the point? Why leave the broken things broken
> at all?
>
> I don't see how bug fixes have anything at all to do with featuritis.
> To me it simply seems that the SF project is dead (certainly no one
> seems to be managing bug reports, even if the RFE forum is considered a
> bit bucket).

If we were to get the problems fixed without adding new features, would
that be helpful? or would we all just then start crying for the
features? (I really don't think new features are necessary.)
